channel.title: How does one go about making the nastiest beats ever?!
channel.description: So I notice a lot of music made with Auxy fails to hit the mark of just straight nasty. In fact I feel most Auxy users aren’t trying to make riddin or DnB... I feel that Auxy definitely has the potential and the sounds for making dirt nasty beats. Any tips welcome here. One thing I’ve found to really help me with making heavy beats is the ability to constantly change shape, time and lowpass

item.title: How does one go about making the nastiest beats ever?!
item.dc:creator: El1011
item.description:
I think u and @Xicon are both right. I have seen tracks with a sub differing in some way to the bass. Usually for different effects. Also if u consider 808’s those don’t usually follow the bass.

But for the most part, people tend to make their sub layers the same as their bass.

item.title: How does one go about making the nastiest beats ever?!
item.dc:creator: HYDRANS
item.description:
you might be referring to something different but normally the sub is like a layer to the bass you’ve already chosen. usually you do this when the bass doesn’t have a strong enough sub bass frequency of its own in which case you would EQ out those low frequencies to make room for the sub

item.source: How does one go about making the nastiest beats ever?!

item.title: How does one go about making the nastiest beats ever?!
item.dc:creator: Xicon
item.description:
Take it from me, I make DnB constantly.

Your idea of a nasty beat depends on the intensity of that type of beat. For example, a nasty beat could include heavy kick and snares. If you have Premium, go look in Neurofunk Collection. If you don’t have premium, the best I can offer is the Charge drumkit.

For the bass, you would need not only a heavy bass, but also include a sub bass. Make sure the sub bass isn’t in sync with the heavy bass. It will sound majorly repetitive. Try playing with some leads, sometimes, they can be used as an appropriate sub bass.

Now, in my opinion, a “nasty beat” needs to be sudden, but also expected. Like, the buildup is more calm, and the drop is out of nowhere. Something like onumi - YOUR LIE.

Well, this is in my perspective. Any disagreements is fine by me.

Read full topic
item.source: How does one go about making the nastiest beats ever?!

item.title: How does one go about making the nastiest beats ever?!
item.dc:creator: eohr
item.description:
i agree indi.
phrygian scale works well.
its super dark because it has a flat 2.
the arabic scale youre referring to is essentially the phrygian scale with a distance of three half steps between the second and third degrees.
these sound super cool because theyre mysterious, spooky, and add that feel of darkness to the music youre trying to get.

Read full topic
item.source: How does one go about making the nastiest beats ever?!

item.title: How does one go about making the nastiest beats ever?!
item.dc:creator: INDIR3CT
item.description:
Go into harmonic minor, and use an Arabic scale. It’s wonderful for making eerie and “nasty” chord progressions and Melodies. Then just layer heavy Reese basses, 808’s, or anything that pitches in to the genre you want to create.

Read full topic
